awd_abstract_narration:
Imagine a future where autonomous vehicles can see through thick fog or even around corners. How many accidents could be avoided, how many lives could be saved, with this form of superhuman sensing? Today, ordinary computer vision systems do not generalize to bad weather or non-line-of-sight obstacle avoidance. This is because ordinary computer vision systems rely on visible light cameras that see colors that our eyes see. To overcome this roadblock, the investigative team will study computational thermal imaging, where novel end-to-end systems are designed with infrared optics and vision algorithms. These topics are usually studied separately. This research program will be integrated into a sequence of newly designed courses in computer vision and computational imaging at the University of California, Los Angeles.

This project brings computational imaging to the realm of long-wave infrared wavelengths and studies the unique performance tradeoffs thereof. The research rests upon three pillars. In the first pillar, the investigative team will construct a 3D camera prototype that projects custom-designed structured light patterns at long-wave infrared wavelengths (circa 10 micrometer wavelengths of light). The structured light patterns may be specialized to the unique characteristics of long-wave infrared wavelengths. In the second pillar, the investigative team will probe deeper into the possibility of non-line-of-sight cameras that operate at long-wave infrared wavelengths. Creating a camera that can see around corners sounds like a daunting challenge, but the investigative team aims to exploit the specularity of reflections that are unique to long-wave infrared wavelengths. Finally, the investigative team will study the foundational differences between how scientists mathematically represent image data at long-wave infrared wavelengths as compared to visible light wavelengths.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Computational imaging combines the power of computer science with imaging technologies to enhance the way we capture, process, and understand visual information. It involves using sophisticated algorithms and computational techniques to extract and transform details that go beyond what traditional cameras or sensors can capture. Computational imaging allows us to extract more detailed and meaningful information from images. By leveraging the capabilities of computers, computational imaging enables us to improve image quality, view objects out of view, and correct informational bias in traditional sensors. This project explores computational imaging in the domain of long-wave infrared wavelengths, focusing on the distinctive performance tradeoffs associated with this spectrum.

To investigate this topic of long-wave infrared imaging, we designed a framework for non-line-of-sight (NLOS) imaging incorporating long-wave infrared technology. Unlike visible light, infrared can see heat sources, allowing us to view NLOS objects as light sources. This simplifies our NLOS problem to a single bounce scenario. While also leveraging certain physical properties of long-wave infrared, we are able to reconstruct NLOS objects with high accuracy. Specifically, we can recover the 2D shape and 3D location of hidden objects with high precision. We have also achieved near real-time and reliable NLOS pose estimation of a human figure, a completely novel application that has not been demonstrated before.

Following this research, we developed an innovative method that utilizes thermal imaging to understand how heat travels and interacts with different surfaces over time. Moreover, as the images produced from thermal imaging look similar to what we see with our eyes in the right conditions, we can use standard computer vision techniques to analyze these images without any complex modifications. This approach allows us to separate and analyze the different components of the thermal image, helping us estimate the surface details of objects. We have demonstrated the efficacy of this technique in real-world situations and complex objects, including those that are black, transparent, and translucent.

We are also utilizing thermal imaging to correct informational biases in our thermal sensors. Thermal cameras and point detectors are commonly used devices to measure the temperature of human skin, but face challenges in accurately estimating temperatures in uncontrolled environments. We explore the specific issue of solar loading, which is the heating effect from sunlight that may disrupt the readings of thermal sensors and disproportionately affects those with darker skin tones. We propose two solutions to correct the solar loading bias. The first approach utilizes the cooling behavior of skin to quickly estimate the steady-state temperature. The second approach involves analyzing the spatial modulation of solar loading and implements a single-shot correction using a wide-field thermal camera. To evaluate our methods, we collected a real-world dataset consisting of thermal point, image, subjective, and objective measurements of melanin, which demonstrates statistically significance for the observed effect size. Our results show that our single-shot correction approach effectively eliminates the solar loading bias within typical frame exposure. By addressing this issue, we aim to improve the accuracy of temperature measurements and enhance the reliability of thermal sensors.

These three projects have achieved significant recognition in the field of computational imaging, being accepted into prestigious institutions like IEEE International Conference on Computational Photography and IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence. Undergraduate, graduate, and postgraduate students have collaborated on these multidisciplinary computer vision projects. Our focus on physics has established strong foundations for future long-wave infrared computational imaging research. Additionally, our commitment to equity empowers students to create fair computational imaging systems for the benefit of humanity.
